title: Quiz 7: Neuroanatomy & Spine
description: Focused assessment on the vertebral column, spinal cord structure, meninges, and the organization of the Autonomic Nervous System (Sympathetic and Parasympathetic).

questions.question: At what vertebral level does the adult spinal cord typically terminate?
questions.explanation: The spinal cord ends at the lower border of L1 (or upper L2) as the Conus Medullaris. In a newborn, it extends to L3. The subarachnoid space continues down to S2.
questions.hint: It ends well above the lower lumbar vertebrae, which makes lumbar puncture below this level safe.

questions.question: Which specific feature distinguishes Cervical Vertebrae from all others?
questions.explanation: Cervical vertebrae have a Foramen Transversarium in the transverse processes (for the vertebral artery). Thoracic have costal facets; Lumbar have massive bodies.
questions.hint: A hole for the artery traveling to the brain.

questions.question: Match the autonomic system with its anatomical outflow:

richContent.content:
SystemFunction
SympatheticFight or Flight
ParasympatheticRest and Digest

questions.explanation: Sympathetic = T1-L2 (Thoracolumbar). Parasympathetic = Cranial nerves + S2-4 (Craniosacral).
questions.hint: Sympathetic comes from the middle of the cord; Parasympathetic comes from the ends.

questions.question: Which of the following ligaments connect adjacent vertebrae? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Ligaments of the spine: Anterior/Posterior longitudinal (bodies), Ligamentum flavum (laminae - elastic/yellow), Interspinous, Supraspinous, Intertransverse.
questions.hint: One of these is in the groin, not the spine.

questions.question: Order the meningeal layers and spaces from Superficial (Skull/Vertebra) to Deep (Brain/Cord):
questions.explanation: Dura (Tough outer) -> Arachnoid (Spider-web) -> Subarachnoid space -> Pia (Delicate inner).
questions.hint: D-A-P.

questions.question: An intervertebral disc herniation usually occurs in which direction?
questions.explanation: Herniation usually occurs posterolaterally because the Posterior Longitudinal Ligament is strong in the midline but weaker laterally. This compresses the spinal nerve roots.
questions.hint: It avoids the strong midline ligament to hit the nerve root.

questions.question: The ___BLANK___ is the tough fibrous band formed by the pia mater that extends from the conus medullaris to the coccyx.
questions.explanation: The filum terminale anchors the spinal cord to the coccyx.
questions.hint: It means 'terminal thread'.

questions.question: Which sympathetic fibers pass through a ganglion WITHOUT synapsing to reach their target?
questions.explanation: Preganglionic sympathetic fibers pass through the coeliac ganglion without synapsing to reach the Adrenal Medulla. The medulla cells act as modified postganglionic neurons.
questions.hint: The organ that releases adrenaline directly into the blood.

questions.question: The Ligamentum Flavum connects the laminae of adjacent vertebrae and contains a high proportion of elastic tissue.
questions.explanation: TRUE. 'Flavum' means yellow, referring to the yellow elastic tissue which helps return the spine to the upright position after flexion.
questions.hint: Yellow ligament.

questions.question: A lumbar puncture is performed to obtain Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF). Which landmark helps locate the safe level (L3/L4 or L4/L5)?

options.text: Highest point of the Iliac Crests (Supracristal plane)

questions.explanation: The supracristal plane (Tuffier's line) connecting the high points of the iliac crests passes through the L4 vertebra or L4/L5 disc.
questions.hint: Hands on hips.

questions.question: Match the Dermatome with its landmark:
questions.explanation: Key landmarks: C6 Thumb, T4 Nipple, T10 Umbilicus, L1 Groin, L5 Big Toe, S1 Little Toe.
questions.hint: T10 is the belly button.

questions.question: What is the collective name for the bundle of lumbar and sacral nerve roots found below the termination of the spinal cord?
questions.explanation: The Cauda Equina ('Horse's Tail') consists of nerve roots L2-S5 extending below the conus medullaris within the subarachnoid space.
questions.hint: Latin for 'Horse's Tail'.

questions.question: Which of the following are signs of Horner's Syndrome (Sympathetic chain injury)? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Horner's syndrome results from loss of sympathetic supply to the head/neck. Signs: Ptosis (Muller's muscle), Miosis (dilator pupillae), Anhidrosis (sweat glands).
questions.hint: Loss of 'fight or flight' in the face.

questions.question: How do sympathetic PREGANGLIONIC fibers leave the spinal nerve to enter the sympathetic trunk?
questions.explanation: White Rami (myelinated) carry preganglionic fibers INTO the trunk (T1-L2 only). Grey Rami (unmyelinated) carry postganglionic fibers OUT of the trunk to all spinal nerves.
questions.hint: White = In (Myelinated). Grey = Out.

questions.question: The nucleus pulposus of the intervertebral disc is rich in glycosaminoglycans and has a high water content, which acts as a shock absorber.
questions.explanation: TRUE. The nucleus pulposus is the gelatinous center. With age, water content decreases, increasing the risk of degeneration and herniation.
questions.hint: It is the soft center of the disc.

questions.question: The primary curvature of the spine (present at birth) is concave ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: The primary curvature (thoracic/sacral) is concave anteriorly (kyphosis). The secondary curvatures (cervical/lumbar) are convex anteriorly (lordosis), developing when the baby holds its head up and walks.
questions.hint: Think of the fetal position (curled up).

questions.question: Which arteries supply the spinal cord?

options.text: One anterior and two posterior spinal arteries
Two anterior and one posterior spinal artery

questions.explanation: The cord is supplied by one Anterior Spinal Artery (in the anterior median fissure) and two Posterior Spinal Arteries, reinforced by segmental medullary arteries.
questions.hint: 1 Anterior, 2 Posterior.

questions.question: What is Spina Bifida?

options.text: Failure of the vertebral body to form
Failure of the neural arches to fuse

questions.explanation: Spina Bifida results from the failure of the neural arches (laminae) to fuse in the midline, potentially exposing the meninges (meningocele) or cord (myelomeningocele).
questions.hint: Bifida means 'split'.

questions.question: Arrange the path of a Sympathetic signal to the skin (sweat gland):
questions.explanation: Lateral Horn -> Ventral Root -> White Ramus -> Ganglion (Synapse) -> Grey Ramus -> Spinal Nerve -> Skin.
questions.hint: Out via White, back via Grey.

questions.question: The Stellate Ganglion is formed by the fusion of:
questions.explanation: The Inferior Cervical Ganglion often fuses with the 1st Thoracic Ganglion to form the Stellate (Star-shaped) Ganglion.
questions.hint: It is at the cervicothoracic junction.

questions.question: Which of the following are features of Thoracic Vertebrae? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Thoracic vertebrae have heart-shaped bodies, costal facets for ribs, and long downward spines (giraffe-like).
questions.hint: Designed to hold ribs.

questions.question: The subarachnoid space terminates at the level of S2.
questions.explanation: TRUE. While the cord ends at L1, the meninges and CSF-filled subarachnoid space continue down to S2.
questions.hint: It goes much lower than the cord.

questions.question: Which structure anchors the odontoid process (dens) of the axis to the atlas, preventing spinal cord compression?
questions.explanation: The Transverse Ligament of the atlas holds the dens in place against the anterior arch of the atlas. Rupture allows the dens to compress the cord (hangman's fracture mechanism).
questions.hint: It runs across (transversely) behind the dens.

questions.question: Match the nerve root injury with its clinical name:
questions.explanation: Erb's (Upper trunk) = Waiter's tip. Klumpke's (Lower trunk) = Claw hand.
questions.hint: Upper vs Lower brachial plexus injuries.

questions.question: What is the name of the vertical bony projection on the Axis (C2) vertebra that acts as a pivot for head rotation?
questions.explanation: The Dens (Odontoid process) projects upwards from the body of C2 to articulate with C1.
questions.hint: It looks like a tooth.
